title: Transformers collector spends £50,000 to achieve Guinness World Record
text:
Louis has quite the collection!

We all want to care about things, but the superfan goes to lengths that far surpass the regular fan.

For eons we’ve worshipped at the altars of sports stars, pop stars, actors, fictional characters, collectables, art, cars, and just about anything else we can relate to, that we can buy, that we can love and share with others.

Also known as a ‘fanatic’ (but, let’s face it, ‘fan’ is much more sexy), these superfans have travelled the globe to support their chosen love, spent hundreds of thousands on merchandise, altered their body in dramatic ways, some have even changed their names – and we’ve tracked down the most die-hard and dedicated to telling their story.

Each week we’ll bring you the story of one keen punter who has dedicated their life and time (and money, so.much.money) to supporting someone or something – simply because it brings them immeasurable joy.

And that’s what life’s about, right?

Say hi to Metro.co.uk’s super fun superfan series, I’m Your Biggest Fan.

This week we chat with Louis Georgiou, who holds the record for the largest collection of Transformers memorabilia.

Full on, right? (Picture: Paul Michael Hughes/Guinness World Records)

Crowned in the Guinness World Records 2020 Edition, the fresh record-holder began collecting Transformers figurines for his son about eight years ago.

Since then he’s amassed a collection worth over £50,000, with the Bumblebees and Optimus Primes quickly taking over his office space and family home in Manchester.

So, Louis – Transformers, eh? When did you start collecting Transformers and…why?

I started about eight years ago. My son was three and I was thinking about a toy franchise to get him into so I could buy gifts for Christmas. I used to love Transformers when I was young and so I looked at the current toy range and it brought back waves of nostalgia.

I bought a load of figures for my son, but then I bought a few for me too, as desk ornaments at work.

The collection has taken over his office and home (Picture: Paul Michael Hughes/Guinness World Records)

I just kept researching different ranges over the last 30 years and got more excited about the newer lines, particularly those aimed at adult collectors and so the collecting habit was started…

What do you collect? Are we talking just figurines?

It’s mostly the toy range, from all over the world and across the full 35 years of Transformers. My favourites are the Japanese exclusives as they have several collectible series that are really cool. I also have a lot of books, comics and magazines.

Advertisement

Advertisement

How many items do you have?

In total, I recorded 2,111 for the World Record, but after I submitted I found about another 50 more.

Wow! Where do you keep them all?

As I was collecting them, I was storing them at work. At first they started to fill my desk, then they spread to other desks, then they decorated our meeting rooms, finally I started filling the store cupboards.

A few years later when we moved office, I had to ship them home and break the news to my wife, who hadn’t realised quite how many I had. At home they filled our basement and attic rooms!

How much money have you spent on your collection over the years?

Just a couple of items… (Picture: Paul Michael Hughes/Guinness World Records)

It’s hard to say. I was collecting solidly for about five-and-a-half years. Some months I was spending more than £1,000 a month on Transformers. So on average I’m guessing around £50,000.

I’ve bought several box sets at around £300. The most on a single figure was about £350, but it came from Japan and I ended up paying a further £100 on import duty/fees!

How do you keep track of them?

Up until the World Record, I didn’t keep any record of them. I bought most of them through eBay so I could look at my purchase history to check, but for years I had a very good memory of what I’d bought and what I was still looking for.

Advertisement

I now have a full inventory which I had to create to submit to Guinness World Records – that took a while to put together!

How did the record title come about?

Randomly one day at work, my business partner asked me what the current world record was. Up until that point I’d never considered it at all, so I just investigated and found out that nobody had claimed a record for Transformers so I thought I’d apply.

Where do you get most of your items?

Mostly from eBay. I used to go to collectors conventions and I’d buy several from there. For the newer figures, there are various online specialists and some Japanese sellers where I’d get a lot of my imported figures from.

Everyone loves a Transformer (Picture: David Livingston/WireImage)

Do you have a prized possession out of your collection?

I actually prefer the newer figures to the originals.

The engineering has improved massively over the years and some of the newer series are incredibly detailed and the Japanese figures are very manga/Gundam-inspired.

I have a few third party figures that look incredible – one is a new version of Beast Wars Lio Convoy, which is visually stunning in robot and beast mode.

Another set, are Takara originals of a Sega Megadrive (which transforms into a Megatron) and a Sony Playstation 1 (which transforms into Optimus Prime). I’m a big gamer too so I love these.

Would you ever sell your items?

Yes! Now they’re home they eat up a lot of space and seem wasted being in storage. I’m planning on selling many of the more valuable boxed ones and keeping the open figures for display.

Advertisement

What do your friends and family make of your massive collection?

I’ve had a mixed reaction. At first, a few family members thought I was a bit strange. Lots of my friends think it’s cool.

I’d say it’s probably cool and strange, if I’m honest. Having a World Record has now validated the obsession.

What is it about collecting that brings you joy?

I’ve had a few collections over the years. There’s a few things that attract me to collecting – I love the deep dive into something, researching and finding out about things and then tracking them down.

I love the nostalgia element and re-discovering things from my past or things of value that are often forgotten.

I love technology and beautiful design or clever engineering, so these are all things that have spurred on my collecting and once I start, I like to have it all!

Dare we ask, what comes next?

I only made it into the GWR book this year, but I stopped collecting Transformers a couple of years ago now and since then I’ve been collecting vintage video games and original arcade machine hardware.

I’m trying to stop that habit before it gets too far as arcade machines take up a lot of space. I’m hoping to have a collecting free couple of years before I get enticed into something new…

Louis’ record features in the Guinness World Records 2020 Edition, out now.
